subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.

messageBody:
Jim Cakalic wrote:
> > Maarten van wrote:
> > > Question: in how far should your production code be
> > > adapted to accomodate testing with JUnit?
> > >
> > > Should it be possible to use JUnit with All/Any form
> > > of Production Code?
> > >
> > > I myself currently frequently encounter the problem
> > > that 'oh, if only this method was not final', 'oh, if
> > > only this class did not have a 'default packagescope'
> > > constructor'', 'oh, if only this class was not
> > > declared final'.
> > >
> > > I tend to override all the methods that I do NOT wish
> > > to test and then let them do nothing, weed out stuff I
> > > do not want to test. But perhaps this is 'BAD' (tm)?
> >
> > I value testing, so I generally do whatever it takes to
> > make code testable. Not everyone values testing as much
> > I do, especially compared to other considerations, so
> > they do other things.
> > --
> > J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
>
> I value testing also. But I guess I'm in the latter group that finds
> other considerations to be of greater importance. I'm not happy with
> stating it that way. I think there is a fundamental interconnectedness
> (in more than a Dirk Gently sort of way) between design and a lack of
> testability. It seems good designs should be inherently testable. If
> one's design attitude is test-first then the two are holistic. Even
> symbiotic.

JBR's postulate 1. For every testable design that requires exposing
elements "just for testing", there exists an equivalent testable design
that does not require exposing elements "just for testing".

In other words, if I add a method "just for testing", I can usually find
a way to restructure the design so that that method either earns its
keep or goes away. I don't have a specific example right now, because
whenever I see one, I don't have time to write about it.

> What I'm talking about here is green-field development. Legacy code,
> as always, trumps best intentions. Sometimes small changes can be made
> that both improve the design and testability. Sometimes changes one
> wouldn't ordinarily accept must be tolerated for the short term to
> improve testability to the point that more sweeping design changes can
> be made with confidence. But if this is consistently happening in new
> development then I suggest stepping back and reconsidering essential
> OO design principles.

The flip side is that I don't value access visibilility keywords. I
don't find them useful. If all data were private and all methods were
public, that would be fine, as is the case in Smalltalk and the default
in Ruby. In Java, I use interface/implementation separation instead of
public/protected/private, because the former helps me for other reasons,
anyway.
